Analysis of Genes in the Endothelial Cluster 1 - Introduction 1.1 Background 1.2 Purpose 1.3 Method

Analysis of Genes in the Endothelial Cluster By: Darshigaa Gurumoorthy 3/19/2021 1 - Introduction 1.1 Background Sexual dimorphism is the condition wherein certain physical traits are displayed by the two different sexes that we associate with cis-gendered males and females which helps in their differentiation. This also extends to their internal reproductive tracts. What is interesting however is the fact that the embryo of these sexually dimorphic organisms is that their embryos consist of the progenitors to both the male and female tracts and it is only around the seventh week of development that this embryo undergoes sexual differentiation, during which one of the tracts, depending on the chromosomal sex goes on to develop while the other is simply discarded. For proper development of these tracts individually, they require adequate nutrition, and for their functioning, they require the the right signalling through the right delivery of hormones. It is hence that vascular network is closely associated with the reproductive tract and develops alongside it. Therefore, it is hypothesized that analyzing these vascular networks and mapping the process of their formation would provide us with some insight into the development of these tracts. Endothelial cells essentially line the inner walls of these blood vessels and play a major role in regulating the exchange between the bloodstream and the surrounding tissue. The signals that they transmit organize the growth and development of the cells that form the surrounding layers of the blood-vessel wall. [Alberts B et al.] 1.2 Purpose The purpose of this project is to analyze the pattern of expression of genes within each sub cluster of the Endothelial cells cluster and hence arrive on the sub cluster that is associated with the reproductive tract. Then further analyze the clusters to determine the best gene to map, to obtain clues into the development of the vascular tract that will eventually provide us with a clue into the development of the reproductive tracts. This experiment focuses on the male reproductive tract. 1.3 Method The genes with an expression of around 400 (+ or - 50) was extracted from the RNA Mouse Atlas published by the Seattle Organismal Molecular Atlas (SOMA). The data was further analyzed to determine which genes were most expressed within each cluster and these were cross-referenced with the MGI Database(Mouse Gene Expression Database) to determine which of the clusters had the most number of genes expressed in the reproductive tract region during the developmental stage. Further, the maximally expressed genes from these clusters were then used to determine which gene is the most appropriate for the experiment. For reference of the analysis of the expression of genes during the developmental stages, the following table was used. Name of Stage Stage of Tissue TS17 E10-E11.25 TS19 E11-E12.25 TS20 E11.5-E13 TS21 E12.5-E14 TS23 E13.5-E15 TS24 E15 TS24 E16 TS25 E17 TS26 E18 TS27 P0-3 TS28 P4 - Adult

Now in the plot below, we see a plot of the expression range of the genes in the Main Cluster. ## Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.0.4 We now sort the above data to find the highest expressed genes. ## # A tibble: 87 x 5 ## GeneName GeneType MaxExpression MaxCluster SecondCluster ## <chr> <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 Ptprm Protein coding 3830 20 23 ## 2 Igf2 Protein coding 2580 20 13 ## 3 Ptprg Protein coding 2210 20 25 ## 4 Mast4 Protein coding 2070 20 34 ## 5 Magi1 Protein coding 2070 20 9 ## 6 Flt1 Protein coding 1650 20 38 ## 7 Mest Protein coding 1600 20 8 ## 8 Dock4 Protein coding 1470 20 33 ## 9 Ldb2 Protein coding 1430 20 1 ## 10 Sptbn1 Protein coding 1380 20 21 ## # ... with 77 more rows Above we see 6 of the highest referenced genes which we now cross reference these genes to find out which ones, if any are expressed in the reproductive tracts during the developmental stage. Gene Name Represented If yes, At What Stage?(Max) Ptprm Yes TS22, TS28 Igf2 Yes TS28 Ptprg Yes Ts28 Mast4 Yes TS28 Magi1 Yes TS28 Flt1 Yes TS19, TS28 From the above table, we can clearly see that 4 out of the 6 genes in consideration are only visible during the TS28 stage, which means that they are not highly represented during the developmental stages. Hence, Main Cluster does not satisfy our requirements completely.

From the above graph, we can observe that the eighth cluster is closely linked with the second and the thirteenth cluster, we can conclude that there is a high possibility that the four clusters are closely linked to the reproductive tract, however previous analysis revealed that the second cluster is not associated with the reproductive tract, hence the three clusters that remain under our consideration are the fourth, eighth and the thirteenth cluster. ***

The cluster that hence remain under consideration are the fourth, eighth and thirteenth cluster.

15 Cluster 13 Sample data from the Thirteenth Cluster: thirteenth_cluster <- readxl::read_xlsx('EndothelialCluster13.xlsx') thirteenth_cluster ## # A tibble: 40 x 5 ## GeneName GeneType MaxExpression MaxCluster SecondCluster ## <chr> <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 2610037D02Rik lincRNA 549 13 14 ## 2 Hpe2 Protein Coding 562 13 4 ## 3 Alcam Protein Coding 607 13 4 ## 4 Eya4 Protein Coding 467 13 4 ## 5 Rora Protein Coding 1230 13 4 ## 6 Col25a1 Protein Coding 416 13 4 ## 7 Sgcd Protein Coding 586 13 4 ## 8 Col1a2 Protein Coding 514 13 4 ## 9 Bnc2 Protein Coding 732 13 4 ## 10 Mid1 Protein Coding 476 13 14 ## # ... with 30 more rows Plot for the genes in the Thirteenth cluster: Ordering the genes on the basis of Max Expression: ## # A tibble: 40 x 5 ## GeneName GeneType MaxExpression MaxCluster SecondCluster ## <chr> <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 Meg3 Protein Coding 2030 13 8 ## 2 Tenm3 Protein Coding 1440 13 3 ## 3 Robo2 Protein Coding 1360 13 8 ## 4 Adgrl3 Protein Coding 1360 13 8 ## 5 Rora Protein Coding 1230 13 4 ## 6 Aff3 Protein Coding 975 13 4 ## 7 Foxp2 Protein Coding 929 13 4 ## 8 Zfhx3 Protein Coding 924 13 8 ## 9 2610203C20Rik Processed transcript 909 13 3 ## 10 Pi4ka Protein Coding 863 13 14 ## # ... with 30 more rows Gene/Representation Table Gene Name Represented If yes, At What Stage?(Max) Meg3 Yes TS20,21,28 Tenm3 Yes TS28 Robo2 Yes TS21,TS28 Adgrl3 Yes TS28 Rora Yes TS22,TS28 Aff3 Yes TS21,23,28 From the above the table, we can see that 4 out of the 6 genes are represented during the developmental stages of the reproductive tract system. Therefore, we can perform further analysis on this cluster. From the above graph, we see that the thirteenth cluster is closely linked with Cluster 4 and 8 as predicted. However, we also see that the 14th cluster also seems to be linked with the 13th cluster. Hence, we now have four clusters - 4,8,13 and 14 under our consideration.

19 Further Analysis - Clusters 4, 8 and 13 As we have seen previously, the three clusters - 4, 8 and 13 are the most associated with the reproductive tract. The following are the top expressed genes during developmental stages by cluster: Gene Name Cluster Representative Stages Represented in Male Tract If yes, what stage? Where? Gpc3 4 TS21,TS28 Yes TS21 Testis Efna5 4 TS21,22,28 No   Nedd4 4 TS23,TS28 No   Fbn2 4 TS20,TS28 Yes-Ambiguous TS20 Dcc 8 TS21,TS28 No   Auts2 8 TS22,TS28 No   Ctnna2 8 TS22,23,28 Yes TS23 Seminiferous cord, testis Ptprd 8 TS23,TS28 No   Meg3 13 TS20,21,28 Yes TS21 Testis, Mesonephros of Male Robo2 13 TS21,TS28 No   Rora 13 TS22,TS28 No   Aff3 13 TS21,23,28 TS21 Testis Therefore, conclusively, we may say that the genes Gpc3, Ctnna2, Meg3 and Aff3 are present in the male reproductive tract during their developmental stage.
20 Functions of the genes during development 20.1 Gpc3 20.2 Ctnna2 20.3 Meg3 20.4 Aff3

20 Functions of the genes during development 20.1 Gpc3 Type: Protein Coding Function: Instructions for making glypican 3. Function of protein coded: Development before birth: regulate cell growth, division (cell proliferation) and survival. Interact with other proteins at the surface of cells to restrain cell proliferation. Gpc3 specifically blocks the hedgehog signalling pathway. 3.May act as a tumor suppressor. May cause some cells to self-destruct (apopstis) 4.May have the opposite effect in some other organs like the liver - may promote growth. (https://medlineplus.gov/genetics/gene/gpc3/#references) 20.2 Ctnna2 Type: Protein Coding Function: May function as a linker between cadherin adhesion receptors and cytosketelon to regulate cell-cell adhesion and differentiation in the nervous system. Required for proper regulation of cortical neuronal migration and neurite growth. It acts as a negative regulator of Arp2/3 complex activity and Arp2/3-mediated actin polymerization thereby suppresses excessive actin branching impair neurite growth and stability. Regulates morphological plasticity of synapses and cerebellar and hippocampal lamination during development. Functions in the control of startle modulation. (https://www.genecards.org/cgi-bin/carddisp.pl?gene=CTNNA2#function) 20.3 Meg3 Type: LincRNA Funtions: Ambiguous information available. 20.4 Aff3 Type: Protein Coding Function: May function in lymphoid development and oncogenesis. Putative transcription activator Binds, in vitro, to double stranded DNA (https://www.genecards.org/cgi-bin/carddisp.pl?gene=AFF3&keywords=Aff3#function)

21 References Alberts B, Johnson A, Lewis J, et al. Molecular Biology of the Cell. 4th edition. New York: Garland Science; 2002. Blood Vessels and Endothelial Cells.
